Hi Tom (+Danny and Lars)

We just need to add the new tags to the Theme taxonomy.
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/coder/_system/taxonomy/themes.xml

I was just about to do this but released (with the values below) that there is a question around whether we are in danger of mixing up navigation labels and tags ie. is "Culture, Ceremonies & Torch Relay" really a tag or a grouping of tags? I think we should be tagging articles to Culture, Ceremonies and/or Torch Relay and if we need to group them in the navigation then do that there. Is 'Round the UK' really a tag, or just a grouping for articles that don't fit into any of the above categories?

Just to clarify, tthe reason we are re-using the 'Theme' taxonomy is that, that is the taxonomy also used by other pages on the site including Photos, Videos etc. so if we want related images and videos to tie in with News and Blog pages it doent' make sense to have two taxonomies / tags (unless you want to also re-tag all the photos and videos)

The one danger / issue here is where we have News articles that are already tagged to the theme Taxonomy (as obv. we are not differentiating between the new tags and the existing ones).

In terms of tagging existing articles, you will need to re-tag News/Blog articles if you want a tag driven navigation, although you probably only need to tag up enough recent articles to fill the navigation (the older articles will still appear under month/year). 

Let me know your thoughts, as obviously it would be good to get this piece of work live.

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Are you free to take a call this afternoon.

I think it would be good to chat about this properly as after a meeting last week it seems there are a few things to work through.

Thanks,

Tom

But the short URL www.london2012.com/Volunteeringhttp://www.london2012.com/Volunteering should work the same as www.london2012.com/Volunteeringhttp://www.london2012.com/Volunteering and redirect to http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/volunteer/index.php.

Original ticket number 1400.

Regards,
Andy

When we made the amendments to the shorturl interface, it was agreed that /existing/ short urls should be left alone - i.e. should carry on being case-sensitive. I do not have the conversation to-hand but I think/presume it was to ensure that no existing behaviour was impacted.
I can go back through and make all short urls ignore case, however it's not a trivial job, as to do it "properly" means generating a list of them, and testing that they all work pre and post-change.
I don't have an example of what might break if I don't perform this test, however I think it for a change of this magnitude, it would be a sensible precaution.

NB Andy is correct regarding "get-involved" being a "real" folder name, rather than a short-url.
We could - if was acceptable to the SEO consultants - enable mod_speling (sic) which would accept urls in any combination of upper/lower case. My opinion is that this would not impact SEO, as we already set "link rel=canonical" headers. However it's not my call!

Kieran

Andy, what do you think about Kieran’s NB?

Also, Kieran could you please quote the amount of work it would be to retrospectively look at the existing short urls?

My view is that we don’t need to look at existing short URLs (although it would be nice if we could tell if they had the case-insensitive attribute), but we should enable the mod_speling thing, which Mr SEO has funnily enough just asked for this last week. His specific comments as follows:

“I typically deploy the following two rules on every web project that I work on:
1. 301 all requests with no subdomain specified to the www. equivalent of the URL (e.g. a request for london2012.com should 301 to www.london2012.com and a request for london2012.com/sports should 301 to www.london2012.com).
2. 301 all requests with uppercase characters to their lower case equivalent. (e.g. a request for www.london2012.com/Sports would redirect to www.london2012.com/sports) - before implementing this ensure that canonical URL can only be specified with lower case characters.
Simple Apache rules exist to implement this logic. Once the rules are in place a request for london2012.com/Sports would redirect to www.london2012.com/sports.”

Kieran, can you comment on doability?

Andy,

Not a critical issue but it would be worth sending this report to KitSite to see what they can do about addressing the overly dynamic URL issues. Some of these URL have up to nine parameters. Hi Andy,

We have already done some work here in that new canonical url tags have everything bar some core parameters striped out, which should help.

For example this url:
http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?q=Athletes%2BVillage&tag=&start=16&sort=&display=list&age=&related=&scores=&user=

Has a canonical url of (ie. it only has the q params):
<link rel="canonical" href="http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?q=Athletes%2BVillage" />

However......

There is a wider piece of work, which I assume David is alluding to, which is /not/ part of the current SEO work, but which has in fact been on our "things we could do to improve SEO if someone was willing to pay for it" ;-) list for a while now, which is to create 'Alias' pages in the CMS.

How this would work is we would create a new page type or thing in the CMS (called "URL alias") which isn't really a page, but could be linked to as if it was a page, the only thing stored with the "URL alias" in the CMS is a descriptive name and a url. This page could then be linked to as if it was a normal CMS page but when the link is rendered the url stored with the "URL alias" page would be used instead.

You could then construct a folder of these Aliases one for each Photo Galley and enter / store the appropriate long dynamic url [ http://www.london2012.com/p:hotos/search.php?q=Athletes%2BVillage&tag=&start=16&sort=&display=list&age=&related=&scores=&user= ] with each one. Then when you link to say 'Venue photos' the href that got output would be the path to the alias (or the short url of the Alias page once we have the SEO stuff done) at the server level we'd output a mod_rewrite rule to say, if you see a link to /venues-photos then do an internal redirect to display the contents of this long url.

If you think this is something that you'd be interested in let me know and I'll try and firm up the exact development required, but as a ballpark in the air expect it would be at least a weeks work.

Jamie
A quick update on this one: Jamie's suggestion of "at least a weeks work" is likely to be an understatement. We think it may be closer to 15 days.

Hi Danny,

If the SEO work will rewmove all but the most important parameters, will you be able to produce a list of the parameters that could appear in a URL? If so then David has suggested using the parameter configuration tool available in Google and Bing Webmast Tools, which will bascially tell these engines to ignore those paramters.

More info here:
http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2009/10/new-parameter-handling-tool-helps-with.html

Regards,
Andy


Andy Watkins
New Media Project Manager
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Ltd
Direct line: +44 (0)203 2012 736
Mobile: +44 (0)7739 574764

________________________________

Any just to clarify,

There are parameters you may not want Google to ignore, for example the Olympic stadiums photos page is (I assume) a real / destination page and one you don't want to exclude Google from indexing.
http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?tag=olympic+stadium

Ideally this would have a nice short / seo friendly url like /olympic-stadium-photos but unfortunately even post the current SEO work we still won't be able to do that.

Although sort, age, scores, page, start etc. are more to do with ordering/format and hence are candidates for ignoring, as they will appear as duplicate content, the q and tag parameters describe the page, you wouldn't want to strip those out or get google to ignore them as they differentiate the different video photo sets.

The good thing though is that even if this page is requested with unimportant query attributes (from a SEO POV) the canonical url will still only have tag= and q= in it (it wont have sort or age etc.)
http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?q=&tag=olympic+stadium&start=1&sort=&display=list&age=&related=&scores=&user=

<link rel="canonical" href="http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?tag=olympic+stadium" />

Now, with regards to which ones are important and which are not, there is no clear answer:

Valid (in that they are used construct a pseudo index page)
-------
q
tag
date, endDate, startDate, period etc. (this one is a bit more contentious, do you ant a URL that describes June events?)
sport (this is probably a high enough grouping ie. Running Videos)
venue (same for venues)
user (used to flag user photos)

Not descriptive in terms of content / only display of that content
-------
start
display
sort
age
related
scores

In terms of a definitive list, it's probably worth looking at the various searches and deciding which parameters describe a page (and so should not be ignored) and which just describe layout/formatting (and hence are just duplicates of the same page).

Photos: http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php
Videos: http://www.london2012.com/photos/videos.php
Events: http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/upcoming-events/index.php (you may want a link to Open Weekend Events to be indexed / listed on Google?)
Suppliers: http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/business-network/oda-suppliers/contractors/aquatics-centre.php (although these do all have nice urls for the contractor, the sectors are dynamic)

Plus the new event schedule search (will you want to deep link to "Diving schedule" or "Greenwich park schedule?")

Jamie

We touched on this during our call on Wednesday and it was agreed that someone would take another look at the overly dynamic urls spreadsheet I provided with a view to suggesting how we might address this issue.

I've attached the latest spreadsheet provided by David.
This one should probably be reassigned to Kieran. Andy is keen for feedback.

Reassigning to you Kieran, as I think I have added all I can to this ticket ;-)

I guess we need to go back with a realistic quote for building some kind of Alias functionality (equal at least to the seo work).

Although TBH I'm not sure how much of an issue (see my separate email) these urls are as the canonical path on all these pages is already tidied up. Maybe that not clear and we just need to reiterate that to Andy . David.

btw. if David is crawling the site the links will still be the long form (as they are in the hrefs and currently need to be) the only thing that has been tidied up is the canonical tag in the page itself.

btw2. I know Andy / David once suggested that we may be able to set up some Apache Alias rules for some of these? The issue here is the hrefs/links in the page would need to follow the same format ie. we can setup /photos/velodrome/ but in the page we'll still have photos.php?tag=velodrome.

btw3. I guess we could trim the search query urls so that any null values are left out (although I'm not sure that will add much benefit, as we strip them out in the canonical paths on the pages anyway).

notes:

- We can look at setting up some kind of 'Alias' feature, whereby the Alias' in turn could have short urls (fairly significant paid for work, which we do need to quote on, but would be good to know if they would consider 10-15 days work 'over the top' for this, before we type anything up / start work investigation what we'd actually need to do; which is work in itself).
- We have already exclude many of these values from the search results pages, if you look the canonical url in the page it is much shorter.
- Some of these values are required (unless we setup Alias') [I have listed them below for example we have a constitunecy-Doncaster is a 'real ' page)
- Using Apache to handle Alias alone only solves the inbound link issue, the links in page will still have multiple parameters.
Also marked as a priority for this week (realistically, probably next week now). Andy is keen for feedback.

Hi Andy,

The short answer is yes we can,

But it may be worth thinking whether it would it be OK to let those urls naturally drop out of Google's index and then get re-indexed, as we are sending a proper 404 page not found headers for them. Obviously if these are inbound links from other sites (rather than just links in Googles site index) then that is another matter and we probably do need to match them up.

The one downside to bulk redirects like this is the server load, as every request will need to first run a check to see if it matches any of those redirects, this may seem insignificant at first, but if we ended up with a couple of thousand redirects that could in turn end up adding a significant load to each request especially which when multiplied up by millions of requests 

If the URL follow a pattern ie. the section name has changed or if any pages in /volunteering should now go to the /volunteer hub we may be able to write a single wildcard redirect which would be more efficient.

So in short, yes we can, if it's external urls from other sites we should (and can we pattern match any of them en-mass?). But if this is just a case of cleaning up Google index it may be better to let Google's indexer go about it's business and drop the old urls and reindex the new ones next time it spiders the site, rather than trying to force anything and clogging up each request with hundreds of redirect lookups (which may grow over time).

Jamie

Andy, let us know if you want us to redirect these (and send us the file) or if you think it's OK to let them fall out of Google index and get re indexed naturally.

Jamie

Jamie,

I’ve asked David to take a look at this. Many of these pages are being linked to from around the web and, if we can come up with a few simple wildcard rules, it’d be good to use these links to build search status rather than just leave them as 404s. I’ll update you as soon as I can.

Thanks, Andy

In that case, it makes absolute sense to redirect them..

See if you can sport an obvious patterns, but don't' worry too much, we can turn a two column Excel doc into a bunch of redirect rules fairly easily.

Have a good weekend

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

We’ve decided the way we’d like to handle this is to 301 redirect 404s up the relevant hub page - so a missing news article would go to the news landing page, and a missing link to something in volunteering would go to the volunteering landing page. The only exception would be where we’ve changed the name of a section, in which case we should obviously redirect to the page’s new location.

Is this achieveable?

Regards,
Andy

Hi guys,

Realise I've been a bit slow on this. Response from David on the 404 proposal is as follows:

"I have included an export of your Google crawl results and unfortunately we are talking about more like 10,000 URL than 300. This will have a significant impact on how this is approached. I think we need to identify wildcards that would forward with a 301 to some new or higher level directory. I am assuming that most of these 10,000 URL are the result of some old URL structure change where no appropriate 301s where put in place when the changes were rolled out. 

The primary strategy is to redirect as many of these 404 to the appropriate pages using 301 redirects. The secondary strategy would be to have a smart 404 page for the 404 not caught by our rule set that uses search to provide relevant links to what the user is probably looking for. This smart 404 page is very much (OPTIONAL) and will not be necessary if we think we can catch most of the 404 with a rule set."

(I've attached the list of 404s.)

Could you take a look and tweak your proposal accordingly - hopefully you'll be able to spot a pattern in the 404 so that rules can be used for the redirects.

I've not commented on the sitemap part of the document as we're handling that elsewhere now.

Thanks,
Andy
Hi, realise you're flat out at the moment, but could you let me know when you'll be able to take a look at this?

I propose the following:
  1. 403's should yield the error page.
  2. For the big list of 404's: Write a script to investigate them. Many will simply be pages which have been moved [A], but still linked-to from elsewhere on the internet. Many might be broken links [B] within london2012.com. [A] we can fix by writing a lookup-table in 404.php, which redirects to a sensible page. [B] we can fix by republishing pages with stale links.

Estimate:
 (1.) 0.5 day.
 (2.) Investigation: 1 day, Fixing [A] 1 day. Fixing [2] 1 day.

Total: 3.5 days.

Cheers,

In the publication queue, display whether or not the publisher is actually running (i.e. whether there's a client_process record for publisher for this client).

subject: CSS validator
description:
The W3C css validator is a java webapp. We need to:
 1. download it (done)
 2. compile it (done)
 3. install it somewhere (perhaps roo, as per html validator)
 4. write a java class to interface with it.
 5. add a workflow trigger, on publication that throws an exception if there's an error in a css asset.
Estimate: 1 days work in total.

(it would potentially remove the need to quarantine some css changes on staging, and is also probably just good practice).

Morag, I am re-requesting this ticket in your name, because I agree with Kieran that it would be a very sensible thing to do, given that issues with stylesheets have caused as much trouble as just about anything else in the past (possibly less so in the recent past as we have been more careful about deploying CSS changes to live and have been able to use staging). 

What do you think?
Yes, happy with this

One last option we haven't yet tried is to pay for a 3rd party white listing service like ReturnPath (previously called to be Sender Score Certified)

http://www.senderscorecertified.com/about/fees.php

I did have a vague feeling Morag looked into this (Morag do you remember anything about it?).

Happy to spend some time investigating the above further, unless you think there is someone better placed at LOCOG to do this on a company wide basis? I expect you also want this to cover email sent on your behalf by a whole bunch of providers.

The pricing for ReturnPath isn't inconsequential and is based on volume so you may prefer to negotiate / handle costs here directly if this is a route you think it is sensible for us to go down.

We should probably close this or alternatively mark as high priority.
Is this so our mail doesn’t go into spam folders? My instinct is we do want to follow-up / investigate. May be something ITS can do. Morag – thoughts?

I agree - this issue isn’t dead – just sleeping.

Please can Kieran provide us with the current stats on percentages of emails for each major ISP which are not delivered / activated? As I recall it was Hotmail which we had the largest problem with, but they are changing their rules all the time.

Priority high.

Here's a summary from earlier this month:

This report shows the success rate of London 2012 users who have signed up in the past 10 days up to September 13.
"Live" means the user has completed the signup-process.
"Not Live" means the user is still in an interim state: They're either waiting for an email to be sent or waiting for it to arrive. The email might be in their junk mail, the link might have been mangled, or they might just not have clicked on it!
Many users will just not have bothered to click, but the difference between, say, hotmail and gmail is likely to be largely due to issues with spam filtering.

					    New    Not	     Success
Email domain				  Users   Live	Live Rate
---------------------------------------- ------ ------ ----- -------
hotmail.com				    220    140	  80	 36%
hotmail.co.uk				    171    121	  50	 29%
gmail.com				            154     48	 106	 69%
yahoo.co.uk				     95     37	  58	 61%
yahoo.com				     81     26	  55	 68%
btinternet.com				     61     20	  41	 67%
aol.com 				     	     40     15	  25	 63%
googlemail.com				     30     11	  19	 63%
live.co.uk					     26     22	   4	 15%
talktalk.net				     18      4	  14	 78%
The table above lost its tabs. In case you can't read it, the highlight is that conversions on hotmail are running at around 36% and gmail at around 69%.
Right. So what do we think are next steps for investigating?
Me to call the two companies above on wednesday

Looking at Return Path's Certification Evaluation Kit (you can get it from http://www.returnpath.net/commercialsender/certification/prequalification/), this looks problematic. They have requirements like "You participate in Windows Live Hotmail JMR feedback loop to reduce complaints. Participation in other available feedback loops is strongly recommended but not required." This requirement involves "Senders register for your feedback loop program at a custom-designed sign-up page, powered by Return Path" and so on. you can read more at http://www.returnpath.net/internetserviceprovider/feedback/

The upshot is that we cannot join the program on LOCOG's behalf, LOCOG will have to do it. I don't see any way of doing this without the direct involvement of ITS--and it is not entirely clear that they would be comfortable with taking this on.

senderscorecertified.com appears to just be a brand name of Return Path.

Kieran, I am reassigning this to you, just in case you have any other ideas about how we might get round this. Otherwise, we will have to think about this again when Jamie returns.

We did discuss the feasibility of sending the signup emails via the 2012 live webservers.
While possibly not actually solving the problem, it would at least put the problem in the hands of someone who theoretically has the means of solving it.

Sending email via the live 2012 servers is not without complication!
What would be the process? We could either communicate directly with a mail server running on web01/other, or we could upload text files containing emails for a local process to send out.
Either way has its pros and cons (and potential implementation bottlenecks!)

There are possibly other alternatives - for example getting a third party to send the email on our (well, 2012's) behalf. We /could/ for example, integrate with Communicator (although they're being phased out, I hear). Some other third party then ... MailChimp or something like that?
picture of proposed solution
Time spent: 1hr - investigating whether PasswordReminder could do this, and drawing picture.

subject: Online form with data export to sharepoint/spreadsheet
description:
From: Kavita Kapoor <Kavita.Kapoor@london2012.com>

We have a new project request. Potentially.

At each venue LOCOG will provide Games Mobility devices, you know
scooters and golf buggies etc.

We may wish to Create an online form via KitSite from approx Nov/Dec
to Apr/May. Information in the form would include; venue (drop down);
date (corresponding to venue); booking out and in times (based on
on-hours); vehicle type (3 in total but varies per venue therefore
these need to line up); name; contact number; email address; and other
comments (an open text box for questions/queries).

Ideally these requests would go direct to a mailbox e.g.
GamesMobility@london2012.com) and LOCOG will respond with a
confirmation or decline email (copy to be signed off by Kathryn) and
fed into SharePoint. However I think we can persuade this team to pick
up a spreadsheet instead like Young Games Makers.

Could I get a price for doing this bearing in mind that we have
alternative ways to service the request.

Kavita
